intro: Abies columbaria, commonly known as the dwarf fir, is a small evergreen conifer native to the mountainous regions of central and southern Europe. It typically grows to a height of only 1 to 2 meters, making it one of the smallest species in the fir genus. The plant has a dense, conical shape with needle-like leaves that are dark green on top and whitish underneath. Its cones are small and cylindrical, maturing to a reddish-brown color. Abies columbaria is well adapted to harsh alpine environments, thriving in poor soils and cold climates.

Due to its limited range, it is considered a rare and relict species in certain parts of its native habitat.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abies columbaria was mainly introduced to specific regions in North America and Europe as an ornamental tree due to its unique appearance and hardiness. It is commonly found in gardens and parks where it is valued for its pyramidal shape and evergreen foliage. The plant has also been introduced to parts of Asia, where it is cultivated for its aesthetic appeal and adaptability to different climates.
